section1.para: We will record here any changes to this resource as a result of developments in the law or practice.

Summary judgment is a crucial procedural device that allows a court to grant a party's claims or defenses before trial (see Practice Note, Summary Judgment: Basic Principles). This Note focuses on how to draft and file a summary judgment motion, opposition and reply. Specifically, this Note covers:

listitem.para: Considerations before drafting a summary judgment motion including:
planning a summary judgment motion;
pre-motion requirements;
the advantages and disadvantages of requesting oral argument; and
outlining the summary judgmmghkjhgent motion.
Necessary papers for the summary judgment motion.
How to serve and file a summary judgment motion.
What counsel should include in opposition to a summary judgment motion.
Limitations of reply memoranda.

section1.title: Initial Considerations
section1.para: Because summary judgment can dispose of a case based on evidence gathered during discovery, counsel should map out the arguments she intends to make, and the evidence needed to make them, before discovery begins. Identifying key documents, necessary admissions and critical facts early in a case and tailoring discovery accordingly can help make a successful summary judgment motion later.

Also, because evidence cited in support of summary judgment must be admissible, counsel should use every opportunity during discovery (whether by deposition testimony, requests for admission or stipulation) to authenticate documents and address any potential hearsay objections (see Supporting Evidence).

section2.title: Review the Relevant Rules
section2.para: FRCP 56 governs summary judgment. Both the local rules of the federal district court in which the case is pending and the presiding judge's individual rules (if any) may set out additional requirements for summary judgment motions. In this Note, local rules includes the court's official local rules, standing orders and Case Management/Electronic Case Filing (CM/ECF) rules. District court websites usually contain links to their respective rules and also may contain links to the judge's individual rules. Links to the websites for all federal district courts may be accessed through the Administrative Office of the US Courts' Court Locator.
Before drafting a summary judgment motion, counsel should consult all applicable rules for guidance on issues such as:

listitem.para: What documents need to be filed when making a summary judgment motion.
How to properly format the summary judgment papers, with some courts or judges setting out rules on:
paper size;
the width of the margins;
line spacing;
the font size of the main text;
the font size of the footnotes; and
numbered paragraphs in the statement of facts (see Statement of Facts).
Applicable page limits.
Acceptable methods of service and filing.

section2.para: (See, for example, D. Mass. L. Civ. R. 5.1(a)(2) and 7.1(b)(4); S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 11.1(b) and 56.1; S.D.N.Y., Indiv. Prac. R. 2(E), Rakoff, J.)

section2.title: Who Hears the Summary Judgment Motion
section2.para: Unless otherwise agreed to by the parties, district court judges decide dispositive motions, such as summary judgment. A district court judge may designate a magistrate judge to review a summary judgment motion. If a magistrate judge is designated and issues a report and recommendation to the district court judge for the disposition of the motion, the parties have 14 days after the report and recommendation is served to file a written objection. The district court judge may then accept, reject or modify the recommendation of the magistrate judge (28 U.S.C. § 636(c)).

Sometimes the parties may have a magistrate judge decide their motion. To have a magistrate judge decide a summary judgment motion, the district court must confer jurisdiction on the magistrate judge and all parties must consent (28 U.S.C. § 636(c); FRCP 73). Once the magistrate judge's order is entered, a party may appeal to the appropriate US Court of Appeals in the same manner as she would appeal from a district court judge's order (28 U.S.C. § 636(c)(3)).

section2.title: Pre-motion Requirements
section2.para: Some courts or judges require parties to take one or more of the following steps before making a summary judgment motion:

listitem.para: Meet and confer with one another about the nature of the motion, the authorities to which they intend to cite or preparing a joint statement of undisputed facts (if required).
Conduct a pre-motion conference with the court.
Seek leave of the court to make the motion.

section2.para: (See, for example, N.D. Ill., Case Mgmt. Proc., Motion Prac., Castillo, J.; S.D.N.Y., Indiv. Prac. R. 3(D), Crotty, J.; N.D. Cal. L. Civ. R. 56.2.)
Counsel should consult the local rules and judge's rules to determine if she must comply with any of these pre-motion requirements (or any other requirements) before making a summary judgment motion.

section2.title: Oral Argument
section2.para: Counsel also must consider whether to request oral argument before moving for summary judgment. There are both advantages and disadvantages to having oral argument on a motion for summary judgment.

listitem.para: Answer any questions and address any concerns the judge may have.
Elaborate on points which were limited in the written submissions due to page limitations.
Focus the judge's attention on the most crucial issues.
Respond to any points raised by an adversary that counsel has not yet addressed (for example, counsel can address arguments or authority cited to in her opponent's reply brief) (see Reply).
Get a feel for how the judge may rule (this could work both favorably and unfavorably).
Weaken a party's settlement position if the judge gives any indication that she is going to decide in an adversary's favor.
Highlight weak arguments which can compromise counsel's credibility before the judge.
Waste time and resources if a judge has already essentially decided the motion on the papers.

section3.title: How to Request Oral Argument
section3.para: Once counsel decides that she wants to request an oral argument on her motion, her next step is to determine how to make this request.

Oral argument requirements vary by jurisdiction. In some jurisdictions, the parties are not entitled to oral argument unless it is directed by the presiding judge or allowed by the judge's rules (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 6.1(c); N.D. Tex. L. Civ. R. 7.1(g); D. Haw. L. Civ. R. 7.2(d)(6)). In other jurisdictions, the rules specifically allow a party to request oral argument. In these jurisdictions, both the moving and non-moving party are entitled to make the request (see, for example, M.D. Fl. L. Civ. R. 3.01(j)).

Typically the request must be in writing and made when the motion or opposition is filed. Some courts require the request to be part of the caption (see, for example, D. Or. L. Civ. R. 7-1(d)) (requiring counsel to include the phrase "Request for Oral Argument" in the caption), while others require the request to be submitted as a separate document (see, for example, C.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 7.1(D)(4); N.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 5.3 ) (requiring a party to file a notice of presentment specifying the time and date the motion is to be presented to the judge).

section2.title: Outlining the Motion for Summary Judgment
section2.para: Before drafting a summary judgment motion, a party should carefully outline each of her arguments and the evidence to which she plans to cite in support of these arguments. Sometimes referred to as an "order of proof," this outline should map out the claims (including all component elements) and defenses and how the moving party plans to prove or disprove each claim. The order of proof typically organizes and details all admissible proof (documents, deposition testimony, discovery responses and so on) in the order in which it would be presented at trial.

In crafting this outline, the moving party must consider who bears the burden of proof for each claim or defense and structure the summary judgment motion accordingly. If the moving party bears the burden of proof for a claim or defense at trial, she carries the burden at the summary judgment stage. To meet that burden, the moving party must cite to evidence which would result in a directed verdict if undisputed at trial. (See Int'l Shortstop, Inc. v. Rallys, Inc., 939 F.2d 1257, 1264-65 (5th Cir. 1991).)

If the nonmoving party has the burden of proof at trial for a claim or defense, the moving party can show that she is entitled to summary judgment by pointing to the lack of evidence supporting the nonmovant's claims or defenses (Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 324-25 (1986)). Once the initial burden is met, the opposing party must then come forward with evidence showing that there is, indeed, an issue of fact which must be submitted to a jury (Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 250 (1986)).
The order of proof can be a useful tool for organizing all of the arguments and supporting evidence for both summary judgment and, if need be, trial.

section1.title: Necessary Papers
section1.para: Many local rules and judge's rules have specific requirements regarding summary judgment motions. While it depends on the jurisdiction, a complete summary judgment motion typically contains:

listitem.para: Notice of motion.
Notice to pro se litigants.
Memorandum of law.
Statement of facts.
Supporting evidence.
Proposed order.

section1.para: Other than the supporting evidence (and the statement of facts if it is incorporated into the memorandum of law), each of the above should contain the caption of the case and a signature block. Supporting evidence typically is attached to a declaration or affidavit that contains both the caption and a signature block (see Supporting Evidence and Exhibits).

listitem.para: Court name.

Title of the case which provides the parties' names. The caption may name the first party on each side of the case and generally refer to the other parties (for example, Party A, et al. v. Party B, et al.).
Docket number.
Title of the document (Motion for Summary Judgment, Memorandum of Law in Support of Motion for Summary Judgment and so on).

section1.para: (FRCP 10(a); FRCP 7(a) and 7(b).) For more information on how to format a caption see Practice Note, General Formatting Rules in Federal Court: Captions.
The signature block should state the attorney's or party's (if unrepresented by counsel):

listitem.para: Name.
Address.
E-mail address.
Telephone number.

section1.para: Some jurisdictions require counsel to also provide her bar registration number (see, for example, D. Mass. L. Civ. R. 5(a)(1)).

section2.title: Notice of Motion
section2.para: Generally, a notice of motion (referred to in some jurisdictions simply as a motion (see, for example, D. Conn. L. Civ. R. 56(a)(4)) identifies the:

listitem.para: Type of motion (in this case, summary judgment).
Applicable rules under which the motion is brought (FRCP 56 and any other applicable local rule).
Relief sought (partial or complete summary judgment).
Date and time of the motion hearing (if permitted by local rules) and the judge who will decide the motion.

section2.para: (See, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 7.1; C.D. Cal. L. Civ. R. 7-4; N.D. Cal. L. Civ. R. 56-1.)

section2.title: Notice to Pro Se Litigants
section2.para: Some courts require counsel to serve and file a separate notice when moving for summary judgment against a pro se party. The form of this notice typically is included in the local rules and generally explains summary judgment and what the pro se party needs to do to oppose it (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y L. Civ. R. 56.2; N.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 56.2; N.D. Ind. L. Civ. R. 56-1). The court also may require counsel to attach the full texts of the local rules regarding summary judgment to the notice (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 56.2; N.D. Ind. L. Civ. R. 56-1).

section2.title: Memorandum of Law
section2.para: The memorandum of law (or brief as it is referred to in some courts) is counsel's opportunity to persuasively argue why her client is entitled to summary judgment. The memorandum of law generally contains:

listitem.para: Table of contents (see Tables).
Table of authorities (see Tables).
Preliminary statement (see Preliminary Statement).
Facts (see Facts).
Legal argument (see Legal Argument).
Conclusion (see Conclusion).

section3.title: Tables
section3.para: Many courts require both a table of contents and a table of authorities (see, for example, N.D. Tex. L. Civ. R. 7.2; D. Haw. L. Civ. R. 7.5(f)).

The table of contents generally lists the pages on which each major part of the memorandum begins as well as each legal argument heading and sub-heading (each legal argument typically is labeled as a separate "point").

The table of authorities generally lists each authority cited (cases, statutes, and so on) and each page in the memorandum on which that particular authority is cited. Some judges require counsel to include in the table of authorities "jump cites" or specific pages within the cases to which counsel cites (see, for example, S.D.N.Y., Indiv. Prac. R. 2(D), Rakoff, J.).

section3.title: Preliminary Statement
section3.para: While a preliminary statement may not be required by a court, it helps to highlight the key arguments. A preliminary statement is basically an introduction to the memorandum. It is a short, concise statement persuasively describing to the court why the moving party is entitled to partial or complete summary judgment.

Although a preliminary statement outlines the legal arguments by referring to facts in the case, it typically contains minimal, if any, cites to case law or the factual record (see, for example, C.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 7.1(D)(1)(a)) (requiring an introduction with no citations). The most effective preliminary statements are those that reduce the arguments to their simplest terms. Facts and legal principles are far more compelling than adjectives and adverbs such as "clearly" and "obviously."

section3.title: Facts
section3.para: Some courts require parties to submit a separate statement of facts detailing all of the facts relevant to the motion for summary judgment (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 56.1; D. Haw. L. Civ. R. 56.1; N.D. Ill., Case Mgmt. Proc., Summary Judgment, Chang, J.), while others require the "undisputed fact" section to be incorporated into the memorandum (see, for example, C.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 7.1(D)(1)(b); D. Or. L. Civ. R. 56-1 (not requiring a separate statement of facts unless ordered to do so by the court); N.D. Cal. L. Civ. R. 56-2 (same)). Regardless of where they are made, all factual statements must be supported with cites to admissible evidence (see Supporting Evidence).

In jurisdictions where the facts may only be included in the brief, the facts generally are set out as they would be in a separate statement of facts, with citations directly to underlying admissible evidence and supporting affidavits that attach admissible evidence (see Statement of Facts). Where the facts are set out in the brief alone, counsel must consult the local rules to determine:

listitem.para: If special formatting rules apply to this section (see, for example, C.D. Ill. L. R. 7.1(D)(1)(b)) (requiring the facts to be listed in numbered paragraphs)).

Whether the jurisdiction's page or word limit applies to this section of the brief (see, for example, C.D. Ill. L. R. 7.1(D)(5)) (stating that the page limitations only apply to the argument section of the summary judgment brief); but see D. Or. L. Civ. R. 7-2(b)(1) (stating that, except for the tables, page limits are applicable to all parts of a summary judgment brief).

section3.para: In jurisdictions that require a separate statement of facts, counsel typically still includes a fact section in the brief to provide the court with an overview of the key facts. In these jurisdictions, factual statements made in the legal memorandum cite to corresponding paragraphs in the accompanying statement of facts which, in turn, cite to underlying documents and supporting affidavits attaching the admissible evidence. (See Statement of Facts.)
The fact section of the memorandum should not be a simple recitation of the relevant facts. Rather, it should tell a compelling factual story of why the moving party is entitled to summary judgment.
There are different strategies to framing the factual issues. For example, a party may set out the favorable facts:

listitem.para: Chronologically. Counsel may prefer organizing the facts in chronological order where the case involves complicated facts, convoluted issues or numerous parties. Setting out the facts in a linear way may make them easier for the court to understand and process.

Thematically. Alternatively, a party may choose to organize the facts thematically. For example, if a defendant is moving for summary judgment on a breach of contract claim and is arguing that the plaintiff failed to establish that there was any breach or that plaintiff suffered damages from the alleged breach, the defendant may want to first describe all the facts that show there was no breach and then separately lay out the facts related to plaintiff's lack of damages.

section3.title: Legal Argument
section3.para: The legal argument section of the memorandum uses legal authority to explain to the court why, as a matter of law, the moving party is entitled to summary judgment on all or part of the case. The central theme to any summary judgment brief is that there is no genuine issue of material fact and the law requires judgment in favor of the moving party. (See Practice Note, Summary Judgment: Basic Principles.)

There are different ways to structure a legal argument. A party may present its argument in the same order in which it would present its evidence at trial, following the structure of the order of proof. Alternatively, a party may put its strongest arguments first to focus the court on the most favorable and persuasive evidence and legal precedent.

section3.title: Conclusion
section3.para: The conclusion typically is a short paragraph at the end of the memorandum that reiterates the moving party's request for summary judgment and refers back to the reasons set out in the brief.

section2.title: Statement of Facts
section2.para: In many jurisdictions, the statement of facts is a separate document in which the moving party sets out each material fact that it contends is not in genuine dispute (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 56.1; D. Haw. L. Civ. R. 56.1; D. Conn. L. Civ. R. 56(a)(1); N.D. Ill., Case Mgmt. Proc., Summary Judgment, Chang, J.).

Although it must be purely factual, each statement should be framed and presented persuasively. For example, if the plaintiff is an employee bringing an employment discrimination claim based on an alleged hostile work environment under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the defendant-employer could frame the facts in its summary judgment motion as follows:

listitem.para: There is no evidence in the record that plaintiff found her work environment to be abusive.

Plaintiff never asked the alleged harasser to stop the alleged harassing behavior. [Cite to declaration or affidavit attaching relevant deposition testimony from plaintiff and co-worker, discovery responses or any relevant documents produced in the case, such as interview memoranda or personnel files.]

Plaintiff never complained to any of her supervisors or any other employer representative about harassment or an abusive work environment. [Cite to declaration or affidavit attaching relevant deposition testimony from plaintiff and supervisors, discovery responses or any relevant documents produced in the case, such as interview memoranda or personnel files.]

Plaintiff never complained to any of her co-workers about harassment or an abusive work environment. [Cite to declaration or affidavit attaching relevant deposition testimony from plaintiff and co-workers, discovery responses or any relevant documents produced in the case, such as interview memoranda or personnel files.]
There is no evidence in the record that the work environment was abusive as judged by an objective standard.

Every one of plaintiff's co-workers who testified on the topic indicated that they did not believe the work environment was abusive or characterized by harassing behavior. [Cite to declaration or affidavit attaching portions of co-worker's relevant deposition testimony.]
There is no evidence in the record that any of the alleged harassing behavior is because of protected class status.

section2.para: Each statement should be short and concise and must either point to the absence of evidence in the record or be supported by citations to underlying evidence. Typically, the citations in the statement of facts are to affidavits and declarations that attach the underlying evidence (for example, portions of deposition testimony, interrogatory responses, documents produced in the case, and so on) as exhibits and certify that each exhibit is a true and correct copy of what it purports to be. For a sample affidavit, see Standard Document: Affidavit: Federal, for a sample declaration, see Standard Document: Declaration: Federal.

Some courts have specific rules regarding the format of the statement of facts, requiring each statement to be in separately numbered paragraphs or imposing limits on the number of paragraphs or pages (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 56.1; N.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 56.1; D. Conn. L. Civ. R. 56(a)(1)). Some courts require the statement of facts to be incorporated into the legal memorandum (see Facts). Still, other courts or judges may require the parties to confer and submit one joint statement of undisputed facts (see, for example, N.D. Cal. L. Civ. R. 56-2(b)). Accordingly, counsel should check the court's local rules and the judge's individual practice rules to make sure her factual statement is in compliance.

section2.title: Supporting Evidence
section2.para: To support a summary judgment motion, counsel must cite to admissible evidence such as:

listitem.para: Depositions.
Documents.
Electronically stored information.
Affidavits.
Declarations.
Stipulations.
Admissions.
Interrogatory responses.

section2.para: (FRCP 56(c).)

For evidence to be admissible, a party must show that it is relevant and reliable (that is, it must be authentic and not hearsay (or it must qualify as a a hearsay exception)) (FRE 401, 402, 901, 801, 802, 803, 804(b), 805, 807). For more information on establishing the admissibility of evidence for summary judgment, see Using Documents as Evidence Checklist.

Counsel may cite to any source in the record. To the extent that it can, counsel should cite to evidence produced by its adversary. Doing so makes it difficult for an adversary to discredit, refute or object to the evidence or its authenticity.
If certain facts are not established during discovery, counsel may submit affidavits to support her arguments as long as:

listitem.para: The affiant has personal knowledge.
The affiant is competent to testify on the matters stated.

The affidavit does not contradict the affiant's previous deposition testimony (Mack v. United States, 814 F.2d 120, 124 (2d Cir.1987)) ("It is well settled in this circuit that a party's affidavit which contradicts his own previous deposition testimony should be disregarded on a motion for summary judgment").

section2.para: Counsel should be wary of citing to her own expert reports in support of a summary judgment motion because:

listitem.para: Statements contained in an expert report are hearsay.
Heavy reliance on experts may give the court the impression that the case will be a "battle of the experts" and should therefore be tried.

section2.para: Unless otherwise provided by local rules, evidence such as deposition transcripts, documents and discovery responses typically are attached as an exhibit to a declaration or affidavit submitted with the motion papers (see Exhibits).

section2.title: Proposed Order
section2.para: Some courts require counsel to file a proposed order with its summary judgment papers. The order should contain language either granting or denying the relief sought (depending on whether the party submitting the form is making or opposing the motion) (see, for example, E.D. Pa. L. Civ. R. 7.1(a); E.D. Tex. L. Civ. R. 7(a)).

section1.title: Serving and Filing
section1.para: Virtually every federal court requires parties to electronically file (e-file) summary judgment motions, oppositions and replies on the CM/ECF system (FRCP 5(d)(3); see also Admin. Office of the U.S. Courts website, Case Management/Electronic Case Files, About CM/ECF). If a motion for summary judgment is e-filed, counsel must consult the local rules to determine if proof of service is needed (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. ECF Rules and Instructions, § 13.2(g) (Jan. 30, 2013)) (not requiring proof of service for papers served on a party participating in e-filing) and, if so, when it should be filed (see, for example, D. Mass. L. Civ. R. 5.2(b)(1) and (2)) (requiring parties to file proof of service with the summary judgment motion or promptly after service); S.D. Fla. L. Civ. R. 5.2(a)). If a party does not participate in e-filing, the moving party must serve the opposing party in the traditional manner and e-file proof of service (S.D.N.Y. ECF Rules and Instructions, § 13.2(g) (Jan. 30, 2013)).

section2.title: What to Consider Before E-filing
section2.para: Before e-filing a motion for summary judgment, counsel should:

listitem.para: Ensure she has a CM/ECF login and password for the court in which she is e-filing.
Carefully review the court's CM/ECF rules which provide guidance on things such as formatting, timing and size limits.

Allow ample time for filing. Although most jurisdictions allow a party to complete e-filing by 11:59 p.m. (local time) on the date the motion is due (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. ECF Rules and Instructions, § 3.3 (Jan. 30, 2013)and S.D. Fla. CM/ECF Admin. Procedures, § 3H(1) (Dec. 2012)), some require the filing to be completed earlier in the day (see, for example, D. Mass. CM/ECF Admin. Procedures, § K (July 2011)) (a document e-filed on the date it is due must be filed by 6:00 p.m. to be considered filed on that day). Counsel should keep in mind that the size and number of different component parts makes filing summary judgment motions time consuming.

Check the electronic docket to verify that all parties to the action will receive the motion via CM/ECF service. Any parties that do not receive CM/ECF service must be served by mail or another acceptable service method under FRCP 5.

Check the local rules for sample language to include in the certificate of service (see, for example, D. Mass. L. Civ. R. 5.2(b)(2); D. Mass. CM/ECF Admin. Procedures § (H)(2) (July 2011); S.D. Fla. L. Civ. R. 5.2(a); S.D. Fla. CM/ECF Admin. Proc. Form B (Dec. 2012)).
For more information on e-filing, see Practice Note, E-Filing in Federal District Court: The Basics.

section2.title: Exhibits
section2.para: Unless otherwise provided by local rule, evidence supporting a summary judgment motion typically is attached as exhibits to a declaration or affidavit submitted with the motion papers. The declaration or affidavit generally identifies the attached exhibits and declares them to be true and correct copies of what they purport to be. A court may also require an affidavit to authenticate the attached exhibits (see, for example, N.D. Cal. L. Civ. R. 7-5(a)). Because exhibits tend to be voluminous, they may exceed the court's megabyte limitation. This is a filing issue that counsel does not typically face when e-filing other motions. To avoid exceeding the court's megabyte limitation for single PDF files (see, for example, D. Mass. CM/ECF Admin. Procedures § (P)(2) (July 2011)), some courts allow or require counsel to:

listitem.para: Include only the relevant excerpts of the referenced documents (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 5.1; S.D.N.Y. ECF Rules and Instructions, § 23.6 (Jan. 30, 2013); S.D. Tex. L. Civ. R. 26.1; D. Mass. L. Civ. R. 26.6(a)).
Simply refer or hyperlink to any pleading or other paper already on file with the court in that case (see, for example, D. Mass. CM/ECF Admin. Procedures § O(3) (July 2011)).

Use a lower dots per inch (dpi) output resolution when scanning documents (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. ECF Rules and Instructions, § 23.4 (Jan. 30, 2013); C.D. Cal. Hardware and Software Requirements for Electronic Filing) (setting out a permissible image resolution range of between 200 and 300 dpi).
Separate the exhibits into multiple declarations (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 5.1; S.D.N.Y. ECF Rules and Instructions, § 23.4 (Jan. 30, 2013)).

section1.title: Opposition and Replies
section1.para: Once a party has moved for summary judgment, the nonmoving party has an opportunity to oppose the motion and, in most cases, the moving party has a chance to reply. This section describes both opposition and reply papers.

section2.title: Opposition to Summary Judgment
section2.para: A party may oppose a summary judgment motion within the time period prescribed by local rules (see, for example, D. Mass. L. Civ. R. 56.1; C.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 7.1(D)(2)).

While the opposing party does not need to file a notice of motion or notice to pro se litigants, the opposition papers should contain all of the other components of the motion for summary judgment. The statement of fact portion of the opposition (whether a separate document or part of the brief) should respond to each statement of fact asserted in the summary judgment motion (FRCP 56(e)). In addition, many jurisdictions permit the opposing party to include an additional statement of material facts (see, for example, S.D.N.Y. and E.D.N.Y. L. Civ. R. 56.1(b); C.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 7.1(D)(2)(b)(5); D. Haw. L. Civ. R. 56.1(b)).
The court may deem facts admitted for the summary judgment motion where a party fails to either:

listitem.para: Submit an opposition.
Specifically respond to each of the moving party's assertion of fact in the opposition papers.

section2.para: (FRCP 56(e)(2); D. Mass. L. Civ. R. 56.1; C.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 7.1(D)(2); D. Conn. L. Civ. R. 56(a)(1); D. Haw. L. Civ. R. 56.1(g).)
Counsel should check the local rules and judge's rules to ensure the opposition papers conform to applicable page and formatting requirements.

section2.title: Reply
section2.para: Most courts permit the moving party to submit a reply to opposition papers (see, for example, D. Haw. L. Civ. R. 56.1(j); N.D. Tex. L. Civ. R. 7.1(f); D.N.J. L. Civ. R. 56.1(a)); but see M.D. Fl. L. Civ. R. 3.01(c) (prohibiting reply memorandum without leave of the court). Reply briefs typically are much shorter than moving or opposition briefs and are limited to addressing the legal arguments and any additional statement of material facts set out in the opposition papers (see, for example, C.D. Ill. L. Civ. R. 7.1(D)(3)). Any fact asserted in the opposition papers to which the moving party fails to address in its reply will be deemed admitted for purposes of the summary judgment motion (FRCP 56(e)).
Counsel should check the local rules and judge's rules to ensure that the reply papers conform to applicable page and formatting requirements.
